title: Question 4
prompt: Why might the early archaeologists’ data be misleading?
description: Click the  <u>one best answer</u> to each question.
feedback:
All of the sites that early archaeologists excavated showed damage from fire, but these archaeologists only excavated areas used by the elite upper class. They determined that the whole city was burned, but they only looked at some kinds of areas, the wealthy areas. The controversy arose when poorer areas of the city were excavated and found unburned. That “only the palaces and temples, areas used by the elite upper class” were excavated shows that only some types of areas were excavated. The conclusion that the “whole city was ravaged and burned” shows that the conclusion was about the whole city.

When archaeologists first studied the city of Teotihuacán, located near modern-day Mexico City, they excavated only the palaces and temples, areas used by the elite upper class. All these sites showed damage from fire around the 7th or 8th century. Early archaeologists concluded that the whole city was ravaged and burned by invaders, possibly the Toltecs.
